title: Questionable content in Firefox Suggest
content:
I work for the Gwinn Area Community Schools, and this is my work computer. (As in, it has never been used for anything 'adult') I searched the term "call" in the search bar, and one of my suggestions was a little dicey. Yelp suggested, "call girl in Gwinn, MI" I just wanted to make sure you guys were aware, in case there are more edge cases like this that could be a lot worse. I would like to continue supporting Mozilla's funding initiatives, but I'm going to have to turn off sponsored suggestions if I get results worse than this.

I just made this Mozilla account to file this, so I was not signed in when this happened. I have searched call very frequently, as I am often adding students to our "call down" list. Not sure if the frequency would have had an impact. Happy to answer any other questions if needed!

Again, I don't think this one's a huge deal, but definitely something to keep an eye on! Thank you for all your work on the hands down best browser!!
creator: zachary.borrett

title: Firefox slow on Windows 10 after recent firefox update (2025) 138.0.3 (64 bit)
content:
Using Google Voice became unusable. Firefox too slow. Had been running just fine up till maybe a month ago when I finally gave in and allowed Firefox to update. Not knowing if it was a Windows or other issue I stupidly did a Windows reset and lost all my installed programs (including Firefox). I did a fresh install of Firefox and manually reentered passwords and bookmarks.

Ran fine for a day or two and is now again unusable. Cleared cache and appears to work OK at the moment but still sluggish.

Finn

title: is it Firefox that is the problem here?
content:
Dear Community,

Would be most grateful for any replies to this post.

Today, I have tried to get into my Outlook e-mail. I usually use Firefox to get into it. But I tried, but the system kept giving me the attached error message - internal service error 500. Strange thing about this was, when I tried to get into my e-mail using my phone, it worked. I then used the library computer, and that worked, too. I tried my laptop again, but this time went into the DuckDuckGo browser. It worked with this.

I therefore assume that the Firefox browser may be the problem.

Can anybody suggest a workaround? Have attached a screenshot of the problem, and the error message that I get, Marek Wesolowski

title: API in directories
content:
This browser is not supported or you are using mobile. The BBMO is only supported on desktop using the latest Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, Opera and Vivaldi browsers.

If you are using Safari or Firefox, consider writing to Apple Support or Firefox Support and asking them to allow Filesystem API on directories.

Copy and paste this message to reach out:

"Please create a new version of the browser app that supports the ability to use FileSystemAPI on directories, this is essential for working with a BeatBuddy project and SD cards that are saved on my computer using the online editor."

title: Han desaparcido todos mis marcadores de la barra de marcadores.
content:

title: page’s settings blocked an inline script because it violates the following directive: “script-src http: https:”
content:
At some point in recent time I started encountering broken websites, and that "http" in their scripts seems like what's causing it. Full error text in the console: Content-Security-Policy: The page’s settings blocked an inline script (script-src-elem) from being executed because it violates the following directive: “script-src http: https:”

what I tried to do to fix this: 1. Disabling https-only mode in settings 2. Disabling all the enabled extensions 3. Tried disabling "enhanced tracking protection" for pages with the errors; and also tried switching tracking protection from strict to standard in the settings 4. Tried checking problematic pages in a new fresh Firefox profile, and they do work there seemingly fine. But I would like to fix the issue for my current profile and understand what's causing it.
creator: vitaliy.planetarium
